title: [dogfooding] App uses constantly 50% CPU on mac m1 even in the background

labels.name: priority 0: blocker
labels.description: an issues that requires immediate attention and that causes the app to not work at all (e.g a crash)

milestone.description:
Communities:
- Token Based Functionality

General:
- User Profile showcase

body: App uses constantly 50% CPU on mac m1 even in the background

Confirming
https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4557972/200272220-01fff674-70b7-4682-ac52-106e7f697b26.mp4
I also noticed quite high spikes of CPU usage on Linux but it was never "constant". I observed 2 patterns: GIF animations and background fetching of message history

On my Windows laptop (a nice laptop, but 3 years old), using the 0.9 release CPU usage hovers around a very reasonable 1.5% to 2% most of the time.    Sometimes it goes down to 0.9%, and sometimes up as high as 2.8% (window visible but not in focus) which is very reasonable and absolutely fine.  For me, memory consumption is around 1.8 to 2.2 gig, which while high-ish is perfectly usable for a windows laptop with 16gb ram.  This is all using Windows 10.

So I think Status Desktop's CPU perf. and memory resource issues are very much OSX specific (or m1 Arm specific?) as resource usage when running Status Desktop on an x86 laptop with Windows 10 is fine.
@alexjba to the rescue :) he found a nice trick to limit the RAM usage drastically

@John-44 @iurimatias The high CPU consumption is reproducible when using an account with Status community. But I think we can lower the priority and not sure it's a blocker. The MacOs Activity monitor will show the CPU usage/Core. This is different than Windows Task Manager where it will show the overall CPU usage. A 50% CPU usage reported on an 8 core Mac is equivalent to 6.25% overall CPU consumption reported on 8 core Windows. It a bit is higher than on Windows, but pretty close (the average I've been experiencing is around 35%/core). I've been profiling the CPU usage while the app is in the background and about 90% of the app CPU usage is used by `status-go`. @richard-ramos @0x-r4bbit Do you think it's normal for status-go to constantly use CPU on the following call stack? This is the profiling data reported by `Instruments`, but I think a Mac is needed to open it: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rBLe1zAteGHYIBNiIGdqtzYxz2YrmP9E/view?usp=sharing
Ouch, this looks like an (almost) endless loop in `watchExpiredMessages`
@caybro trying to interpret that stack. Where do you see that it's an endless loop?

> @caybro trying to interpret that stack. Where do you see that it's an endless loop?

Well, I meant sth that gets called way too often

Let's see what up: `resendExpiredMessages` is executed every 1s according to this - https://github.com/status-im/status-go/blob/develop/protocol/messenger.go#L1320-L1338 and what the function does is attempt to retrieve the expired messages from the DB. (https://github.com/status-im/status-go/blob/develop/protocol/messenger.go#L571-L614)

Perhaps we're in dire need of adding an index to speed up this query: https://github.com/status-im/status-go/blob/develop/protocol/persistence.go#L822-L831

> @alexjba could you execute this in your DB and see if the performance improves?
> 
> ```
> CREATE INDEX raw_messages_expired_idx ON raw_messages (message_type, sent, send_count);
> ```

Sure, I'll give it a try later today.

Meanwhile I've been busy compiling the app for M1. And I've been able to run it and get some data out of it. The CPU consumption looks much better. I've seen numbers as low as 7% CPU usage while using the app which was a first for me. Usually it roams around 15-20%, with around 10% while the app is in the background.

One drawback I have now it that I use [Address Sanitizer](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/AddressSanitizer.html) on the nim build in order to call status-go API without freezing. It's consuming both CPU and memory.
@richard-ramos I've seen you logged in a go issue on it (https://github.com/golang/go/issues/48437). Do you have more insights on it?
The arm build looks really promising in terms of CPU performance and I would love to see it working!
i can confirm that on 0.10 it roams around 15-20%, but its doesn't drop for me in the background, no changes

@richard-ramos doesn't have his laptop, so he can't comment here, so here is his answer:

> So, regarding this,
I think this was a problem in go1. 17
And Stefan did try in newer go versions
And things were working
I remember jakub also changing the makefile to remove the code that transpiled statusgo to amd64, so builds on m1 would build for arm
But dunno the status of that. Its been a while

> @alexjba could you execute this in your DB and see if the performance improves?
> 
> ```
> CREATE INDEX raw_messages_expired_idx ON raw_messages (message_type, sent, send_count);
> ```

Very good finding @richard-ramos! The CPU usage improvement I see is impressive. Without index I get about 45% CPU usage, with the index I get about 15% CPU. Can you add it to `status-go`?

> > @alexjba could you execute this in your DB and see if the performance improves?
> > ```
> > CREATE INDEX raw_messages_expired_idx ON raw_messages (message_type, sent, send_count);
> > ```
> 
> Very good finding @richard-ramos! The CPU usage improvement I see is impressive. Without index I get about 45% CPU usage, with the index I get about 15% CPU. Can you add it to `status-go`?

@jrainville @alexjba - @richard-ramos has just started his parental leave (congrats @richard-ramos :-) ), would anybody else be able to add this to `status-go` so we can get this improvement into 0.11 ?
Nice find @richard-ramos @alexjba , here's a PR adding the index https://github.com/status-im/status-go/pull/3285
Can confirm this has massively decreased my CPU usage, there is still work to do but this definitely makes a big difference.

Interesting that we don't see that on mobile, I wonder if it's possible that how things are compiled for desktop (sqlite/cipher) make it somehow slower? I'd expect to be even worse on mobile, but odd that we don't see this

i don't think we tested CPU on mobile for latest builds with waku2 and communities
im wondering why the index in  raw_messages has an effect even if there are no new messages? so we are testing CPU usage when app is IDLE right ?

> 

It's true, though that code has been there for a while, but maybe it's possible that we are storing much more raw messages if you joined a community? Worth having a look
yeah would be great to monitor write/read operations for raw_messsages, probably there is a bug/mistake which causes hight CPU usage ,and adding index we just hide the root cause
Yeah, I'm also surprised that such an index improved so much. There might be an underlying problem of too many messages being stored in raw_messages.
Closed by https://github.com/status-im/status-go/pull/3285
